title: Hosea Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hosea chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hosea Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hosea Chapter 7.

questions.question: According to Hosea 7:1, what was discovered when God wanted to heal Israel?
options: The iniquity of Ephraim and the wickedness of Samaria
questions.correctAnswer: The iniquity of Ephraim and the wickedness of Samaria
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:1 states that when God wanted to heal Israel, He discovered the iniquity of Ephraim and the wickedness of Samaria.

questions.question: What do the people of Israel commit according to Hosea 7:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Falsehood
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:1 says that the people commit falsehood among other sins.

questions.question: What do the people fail to consider in their hearts according to Hosea 7:2?
options: That God remembers all their wickedness
questions.correctAnswer: That God remembers all their wickedness
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:2 states that they do not consider that God remembers all their wickedness.

questions.question: Who do the people make glad with their wickedness, according to Hosea 7:3?
questions.correctAnswer: The king and the princes
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:3 says they make the king glad with their wickedness and the princes with their lies.

questions.question: Hosea 7:4 compares the people to what kind of object?
options: An oven heated by the baker
questions.correctAnswer: An oven heated by the baker
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:4 describes them as adulterers like an oven heated by the baker.

questions.question: What has made the king sick according to Hosea 7:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Bottles of wine
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:5 states that princes have made the king sick with bottles of wine.

questions.question: According to Hosea 7:7, what have the people devoured?
questions.correctAnswer: Their judges
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:7 says they have devoured their judges and all their kings have fallen.

questions.question: In Hosea 7:8, Ephraim is compared to what food?
questions.correctAnswer: A cake not turned
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:8 compares Ephraim to a cake not turned.

questions.question: Who has devoured Ephraim's strength according to Hosea 7:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:9 says strangers have devoured Ephraim's strength.

questions.question: According to Hosea 7:11, Ephraim calls to which two nations?
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt and Assyria
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:11 states Ephraim calls to Egypt and goes to Assyria.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 7:10 says the pride of Israel causes them to return to the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:10 says the pride of Israel testifies against them and they do not return to the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 7:13 says God has redeemed Israel despite their transgressions.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:13 acknowledges God has redeemed them even though they have spoken lies against Him.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 7:16 describes the princes as strong and faithful bows.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:16 says they are like a deceitful bow, not faithful.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'Though I have bound and strengthened their _______, yet do they imagine mischief against me.'
questions.correctAnswer: arms
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:15 says God has bound and strengthened their arms, yet they imagine mischief.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'They assemble themselves for corn and _______, and they rebel against me.'
questions.correctAnswer: wine
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:14 states they assemble themselves for corn and wine and rebel against God.

medium.title: Hosea Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hosea Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with guilt over past sins and asks you for counsel. Based on Hosea 7:1, what biblical truth would you share about God's willingness to heal?
options: God desires to heal Israel despite their sin
God has abandoned Israel because of their sins
God ignores the sins of Israel
God only heals those without sin
questions.correctAnswer: God desires to heal Israel despite their sin
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:1 states that God would have healed Israel but their iniquity was discovered. This shows God's desire to heal despite their sins. Verses 10, 13, and 14 further demonstrate God's patience and call for repentance.

questions.question: How does Hosea 7:2 teach us about God's awareness of our actions and the importance of sincere repentance?
options: God remembers all wickedness and our deeds surround us
God forgets our sins if we pray once
questions.correctAnswer: God remembers all wickedness and our deeds surround us
questions.explanation: Verse 2 emphasizes that God remembers all wickedness and that our own actions entangle us. This teaches believers to be sincere in repentance because God sees all. Verses 10 and 14 also highlight the need for heartfelt turning to God.

questions.question: A church leader is tempted to please others through dishonesty. According to Hosea 7:3, what is the consequence of such behavior?
options: They make the king glad with their wickedness
questions.correctAnswer: They make the king glad with their wickedness
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:3 says they make the king glad with wickedness and princes with lies, indicating that dishonesty leads to corrupt approval rather than God's favor. This warns against pleasing people through sin. See also verses 15 and 16 for consequences.

questions.question: How does Hosea 7:4 use the metaphor of an oven and baker to describe spiritual unfaithfulness, and what practical lesson does this teach about perseverance in faith?
options: They are like an oven heated but left unattended, leading to corruption
They are like a well-watered garden
They are like a stone unchanging
questions.correctAnswer: They are like an oven heated but left unattended, leading to corruption
questions.explanation: Verse 4 compares adulterers to an oven heated by a baker who stops working, causing the dough to be leavened improperly. This shows that neglecting spiritual discipline allows sin to grow. Verses 6 and 7 reinforce how hidden sin can burn destructively.

questions.question: In a family setting, how does Hosea 7:5 warn about the impact of indulgence and mockery on leadership and relationships?
options: Princes are made sick with wine and extend their hands to scorners
Indulgence brings peace to the household
questions.correctAnswer: Princes are made sick with wine and extend their hands to scorners
questions.explanation: Verse 5 describes princes made sick by wine and reaching out to mockers, implying that indulgence and scorn harm leadership and relationships. This teaches the importance of self-control and respect. See also verses 7 and 15 for consequences of such behavior.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with hidden sin that grows unnoticed. According to Hosea 7:6, what is the nature of this hidden sin, and what practical advice does it offer?
options: Sin may lie dormant but burns fiercely when awakened
Sin is always obvious and easily dealt with
questions.correctAnswer: Sin may lie dormant but burns fiercely when awakened
questions.explanation: Verse 6 uses the analogy of a baker sleeping while the oven burns as a flaming fire in the morning, illustrating that hidden sin can flare up destructively. This warns believers to remain vigilant in spiritual discipline. Verses 4 and 7 support this teaching.

questions.question: How does Hosea 7:7 illustrate the consequences of not seeking God in leadership, and what does it teach about humility and dependence on God?
options: Kings fall and judges are devoured because none call to God
questions.correctAnswer: Kings fall and judges are devoured because none call to God
questions.explanation: Verse 7 highlights that all are hot as an oven and have devoured their judges, with fallen kings because none call to God. This teaches that humility and seeking God are essential for stable leadership and life. Verses 10 and 16 reinforce this truth.

questions.question: What practical warning does Hosea 7:9 provide about ignoring the effects of sin and aging without spiritual awareness?
options: Strangers devour strength and gray hairs appear, yet they do not know
Sin has no effect on strength
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers devour strength and gray hairs appear, yet they do not know
questions.explanation: Verse 9 warns that strangers consume strength and gray hairs appear, but the people are unaware, teaching the danger of spiritual blindness and ignoring the consequences of sin. Verses 10 and 14 emphasize the need for heartfelt repentance.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to rely on foreign alliances rather than God. According to Hosea 7:11, what does this passage teach about trust and dependence?
options: Ephraim is like a silly dove calling to Egypt and going to Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: Ephraim is like a silly dove calling to Egypt and going to Assyria
questions.explanation: Verse 11 compares Ephraim to a silly dove without heart, turning to Egypt and Assyria instead of God. This teaches the importance of trusting God rather than worldly powers. Verses 12 and 13 speak of God's judgment for such misplaced trust.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 7:10 teaches that despite Israel's pride, they return to the LORD and seek Him earnestly.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:10 states that the pride of Israel testifies against them and that they do not return to the LORD nor seek Him despite their circumstances, indicating stubbornness rather than repentance.

questions.question: How does Hosea 7:13 teach about God's response to those who flee from Him and transgress despite being redeemed?
options: Woe and destruction come upon those who flee and lie against God
questions.correctAnswer: Woe and destruction come upon those who flee and lie against God
questions.explanation: Verse 13 pronounces woe and destruction on those who flee God and speak lies against Him despite redemption. This teaches the seriousness of rebellion and encourages repentance. Verses 14 and 15 also highlight rebellion and mischief against God.

questions.question: A believer feels their prayers are unanswered when they cry out in distress. According to Hosea 7:14, what might be the reason and how should they respond?
options: They have not cried to God with their heart and rebel against Him
questions.correctAnswer: They have not cried to God with their heart and rebel against Him
questions.explanation: Verse 14 explains that though they howl on their beds, they have not prayed sincerely with their hearts and continue in rebellion. This teaches the need for genuine repentance and heartfelt prayer. See also verses 10 and 13.

questions.question: What does Hosea 7:15 reveal about God's strength given to His people and their response, and how does this inform our attitude towards God's provision?
options: God strengthens their arms, but they imagine mischief against Him
questions.correctAnswer: God strengthens their arms, but they imagine mischief against Him
questions.explanation: Verse 15 states that God has strengthened Israel's arms, yet they devise evil against Him, demonstrating ingratitude and rebellion. This teaches believers to respond with gratitude and obedience to God's provision. See also verses 1 and 13.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 7:16 depicts the people returning to God wholeheartedly and their princes rising in favor.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 16 says they return but not to the Most High, likening them to a deceitful bow, and that their princes will fall by the sword, indicating unfaithfulness and judgment rather than true return.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hosea 7:8 describes Ephraim as a cake not __________, symbolizing incomplete transformation and spiritual failure.
questions.correctAnswer: turned
questions.explanation: Verse 8 states 'Ephraim is a cake not turned,' meaning incomplete or imperfect, symbolizing spiritual failure and unrepentance. This metaphor teaches the need for thorough transformation. Related verses include 4 and 6.

hard.title: Hosea Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hosea Chapter 7.

questions.question: In Hosea 7:1, what is revealed when God intended to heal Israel?
options: The iniquity of Ephraim and the wickedness of Samaria
questions.correctAnswer: The iniquity of Ephraim and the wickedness of Samaria
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:1 states that when God would have healed Israel, the iniquity of Ephraim and the wickedness of Samaria were discovered, showing their moral failure.

questions.question: According to Hosea 7:2, what do the people fail to consider in their hearts?
options: That God remembers all their wickedness
That the temple will be rebuilt
That the covenant will be renewed
questions.correctAnswer: That God remembers all their wickedness
questions.explanation: Verse 7:2 explains that the people do not consider that God remembers all their wickedness, and their own actions have trapped them before God’s face.

questions.question: What analogy is used in Hosea 7:4 to describe the adulterous nature of the people?
options: An oven heated by the baker
questions.correctAnswer: An oven heated by the baker
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:4 uses the image of an oven heated by the baker who stops raising the dough until it is leavened, symbolizing the growing corruption and adulterous behavior.

questions.question: In Hosea 7:7, what is described as being devoured by the hot oven-like people?
questions.correctAnswer: Their judges
questions.explanation: The verse metaphorically states that the people, like a hot oven, have devoured their judges, highlighting the breakdown of just leadership.

questions.question: How does Hosea 7:8 describe Ephraim’s mingling with other peoples?
options: As a tree planted by water
questions.correctAnswer: As a cake not turned
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:8 uses the metaphor of Ephraim mixing among the peoples and being like a cake not turned, indicating incomplete transformation and instability.

questions.question: What does Hosea 7:9 reveal about Ephraim’s awareness of its own condition?
options: Strangers have devoured his strength, yet he knows it not
He is fully aware of his sins
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers have devoured his strength, yet he knows it not
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes Ephraim’s ignorance of its weakening by strangers, despite visible signs like gray hairs.

questions.question: According to Hosea 7:10, what does the pride of Israel do?
questions.correctAnswer: Testify to his face
questions.explanation: The pride of Israel openly testifies against them, yet they do not return to the LORD nor seek Him, as stated in Hosea 7:10.

questions.question: Hosea 7:11 portrays Ephraim as what kind of bird, symbolizing foolishness?
questions.correctAnswer: A silly dove without heart
questions.explanation: Ephraim is likened to a silly dove without heart, showing their senselessness in calling to Egypt and Assyria instead of trusting God.

questions.question: What consequence does God declare in Hosea 7:12 for Ephraim’s reliance on foreign alliances?
options: God will spread a net upon them and bring them down like fowls of heaven
God will bless their military campaigns
God will establish a new covenant with them
God will provide them with abundant harvests
questions.correctAnswer: God will spread a net upon them and bring them down like fowls of heaven
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:12 warns that God will trap Ephraim as they trust in foreign powers, symbolizing impending judgment.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hosea 7:13, despite God’s redemption, Israel has spoken lies against Him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:13 explicitly states that although God redeemed them, Israel has transgressed and spoken lies against Him.

questions.question: In Hosea 7:14, what do the people do instead of crying out to God with their heart?
options: They assemble themselves for corn and wine and rebel
They build altars to the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: They assemble themselves for corn and wine and rebel
questions.explanation: The verse reveals the people's insincere lamentation and their rebellion through indulgence in corn and wine.

questions.question: Despite God binding and strengthening their arms in Hosea 7:15, what do the people imagine?
questions.correctAnswer: Mischief against God
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:15 indicates that even with God's support, the people contrive evil plans against Him.

questions.question: Hosea 7:16 compares the return of the people to what kind of object, highlighting their deceitfulness?
questions.correctAnswer: A deceitful bow
questions.explanation: The people’s return is likened to a deceitful bow that cannot be trusted to hit its mark, symbolizing their unfaithfulness.

questions.question: Which foreign nations are mentioned in Hosea 7:11 as places Ephraim calls to for help?
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt and Assyria
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:11 highlights Ephraim’s foolish reliance on Egypt and Assyria instead of God.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Hosea 7:4 when describing the adulterous behavior of the people?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The verse uses a simile comparing the people to an oven heated by the baker, illustrating the process and consequences of their adulterous deeds.

theological.title: Hosea Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hosea Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Hosea 7:1, what did God's desire to heal Israel reveal about Ephraim and Samaria?
options: Their iniquity and wickedness were discovered
questions.correctAnswer: Their iniquity and wickedness were discovered
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:1 shows that when God sought to heal Israel, He found the iniquity of Ephraim and the wickedness of Samaria, indicating their sinful state. This reflects God's holiness and justice, consistent with passages like Psalm 7:11 and Romans 3:23, which emphasize human sinfulness and God's righteous judgment.

questions.question: What does Hosea 7:2 indicate about God's awareness of Israel's actions?
options: He is unaware of their deeds
questions.correctAnswer: He remembers all their wickedness
questions.explanation: Verse 2 emphasizes God's omniscience and justice, showing that He remembers all wicked acts, consistent with Deuteronomy 32:35 and Hebrews 10:30 which affirm God's memory and judgment of sin.

questions.question: In Hosea 7:3, how do the people affect their king and princes?
options: They make the king glad with their wickedness
They bring them peace and righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: They make the king glad with their wickedness
questions.explanation: Hosea 7:3 reveals that the people's wickedness pleases their king and princes, demonstrating corruption and moral failure in leadership, paralleling Proverbs 29:2 and Romans 1:32 about leaders and people sharing in sin.

questions.question: Hosea 7:4 compares the people to what metaphor related to adulterers?
options: An oven heated by the baker
questions.correctAnswer: An oven heated by the baker
questions.explanation: The metaphor in verse 4 illustrates how their sinful desires grow uncontrollably, like an oven heated but neglected, symbolizing persistent sinfulness; similar imagery is used in Jeremiah 18:6 about the potter and clay, highlighting God's control over human hearts.

questions.question: What effect do the princes have on their king according to Hosea 7:5?
options: They have made him sick with bottles of wine
They have strengthened him in righteousness
They have protected him from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: They have made him sick with bottles of wine
questions.explanation: This verse shows the moral decay and indulgence affecting leadership, symbolizing spiritual and physical weakness caused by sin, paralleling Proverbs 23:29-35 warning against wine's dangers and Isaiah 28:7 about leaders erring through intoxication.

questions.question: How is the heart of the people described in Hosea 7:6?
options: Made ready like an oven while they lie in wait
questions.correctAnswer: Made ready like an oven while they lie in wait
questions.explanation: The verse uses the oven metaphor to depict their readiness to sin and deception, showing deliberate rebellion, consistent with Jeremiah 17:9 and Ezekiel 11:19 about hearts prepared for wickedness.

questions.question: What does Hosea 7:7 say about the people's relationship with God and their leaders?
options: All have devoured their judges and none calls unto God
They honor their judges and seek God diligently
They rely on God and their kings
They are united under God’s guidance
questions.correctAnswer: All have devoured their judges and none calls unto God
questions.explanation: This verse highlights the rejection of God's authority and leadership, showing societal collapse and apostasy, aligning with 1 Samuel 8:7 and Romans 1:28 concerning the consequences of rejecting divine rule.

questions.question: In Hosea 7:8, what is Ephraim compared to and what does it signify?
options: A cake not turned, signifying incompleteness and corruption
questions.correctAnswer: A cake not turned, signifying incompleteness and corruption
questions.explanation: The 'cake not turned' metaphor indicates Ephraim’s failure to be properly transformed or purified, reflecting spiritual stagnation and impurity, similar to Malachi 2:3 about offering corrupt sacrifices and Romans 12:2 on transformation.

questions.question: What does Hosea 7:9 reveal about Ephraim's condition despite his strength?
options: Strangers have devoured his strength, yet he knows it not
He is fully aware and repents
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers have devoured his strength, yet he knows it not
questions.explanation: This shows Ephraim’s spiritual blindness and vulnerability to external enemies, reflecting themes of ignorance and judgment found in Isaiah 5:13 and Romans 1:21 about failing to acknowledge God’s hand.

questions.question: How does Hosea 7:10 describe Israel’s attitude despite God’s dealings with them?
options: Their pride testifies against them and they do not return to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Their pride testifies against them and they do not return to the LORD
questions.explanation: The verse stresses the stubborn pride and refusal to repent, consistent with Proverbs 16:18 and Luke 18:9-14 about the dangers of pride and the need for humility before God.

questions.question: What does Hosea 7:11 compare Ephraim to, and what is the significance?
options: A silly dove without heart, calling to Egypt and going to Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: A silly dove without heart, calling to Egypt and going to Assyria
questions.explanation: This metaphor illustrates Ephraim’s foolishness and lack of faith, seeking help from foreign powers rather than God, echoing Isaiah 31:1 and Jeremiah 2:18 about misguided alliances.

questions.question: What is God's response to Israel’s attempts to seek help from other nations as per Hosea 7:12?
options: He will spread his net and bring them down as fowls of heaven
questions.correctAnswer: He will spread his net and bring them down as fowls of heaven
questions.explanation: God warns of judgment for Israel’s misplaced trust, symbolized by a net catching birds, indicating inevitable punishment, consistent with Psalm 91:3 and Proverbs 1:17 about traps set for the wicked.

questions.question: According to Hosea 7:13, why is destruction pronounced on Israel despite God’s redemption?
options: Because they have transgressed and spoken lies against God
Because they have obeyed the law
questions.correctAnswer: Because they have transgressed and spoken lies against God
questions.explanation: Though redeemed, Israel’s continued rebellion and deceit provoke God’s wrath, affirming the principle of divine justice in Exodus 34:7 and Hebrews 10:26-27 about consequences of persistent sin.

questions.question: Hosea 7:14 portrays Israel’s hypocrisy by stating they have not done what sincerely?
options: Cried unto God with their heart
questions.correctAnswer: Cried unto God with their heart
questions.explanation: The verse highlights the superficiality of Israel’s worship, lacking heartfelt repentance, consistent with Isaiah 29:13 and Matthew 15:8 on empty worship without true devotion.

questions.question: What does Hosea 7:15 say about God’s strengthening of Israel’s arms and their response?
options: Though strengthened, they imagine mischief against God
They use strength to serve God faithfully
questions.correctAnswer: Though strengthened, they imagine mischief against God
questions.explanation: This verse describes Israel’s ungrateful rebellion despite God’s support, reflecting human sinfulness and stubbornness, parallel to Psalm 78:41 and Romans 1:21 about rejecting God's benefits.
